titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Aden Field Papers, 1940s-2015 and undated RL.11346
titlestmt.author: Ben Saalfeld, Meghan Lyon

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2016-12-17 14:10:57 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Aden Field is an author and poet from Durham, North Carolina, who co-founded the Regulator along with other Durham community organizations. This collection consists of his journals, writings, postcard collections, community projects and files, and his collection of correspondence and writings from friends and family. It documents his friendships and relationships, Durham community events and activities, and his career as a writer and teacher in North Carolina.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into series: Journals, Postcard Binders, Writings, Businesses and Projects, Name and Correspondence Files, and Personal Materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Aden Field is an author, playwright, and poet based in Durham, North Carolina. He was born in 1938 in McKenzie, Tennessee, and graduated from Harvard University in 1959. Field attended Duke University until 1966, when he withdrew from courses but stayed in Durham. He and several friends co-founded The Regulator bookshop in 1976, located on Ninth Street in Durham. Field also helped found and manage groups and publications such as Urban Hiker, WDBS Guide, Black Mountain Project, and Collaborations of the Creative and the Sacred, Inc.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Aden Field Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2016.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Aden Field Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Ben Saalfeld and Meghan Lyon, Dec. 2016
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2016-0114

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: This collection includes Field's correspondence, writings, journals, postcard binders, and files from his management and work at The Regulator, Collaborations, Black Mountain Project, Urban Hiker, and several local arts councils and youth writing programs. Materials have been sorted into series but largely remain labeled and foldered according to Field's own arrangement scheme.

Field's Journals Series contain incredibly detailed chapters of his life, which were created and re-typed by Field as a project in the 1990s. Early journals are volumes 1-4; he began titling them in the 1980s. Entries include his daily activities, Durham news, horoscope (I Ching), financial spending, and introspective analysis of his thoughts, writings, and relationships. Binders are dated and sorted by date, YYMMDD.

Field's postcard binders project began in the 1990s to assemble a Book of Men, featuring postcards of images of men in art from art galleries around the world. Other binders he created included postcards documenting American society and culture from the nineteenth century through the 1990s. He also created a Book of Women and collected assorted postcards that remain unassembled into binders, all held in this series.

Field's writings range from poetry to plays to prose, and the Writings Series includes drafts and published versions arranged in both chronological and alphabetical files. The chron files are dated YYMMDD. The alphabetical files are arranged by title.

Field's many businesses and projects are sorted by group name, with some groups' files containing only one or two items and some groups filling an entire box (see especially Collaborations, The Regulator, and Urban Hiker). These files include correspondence, publications, board minutes, notes by Field, and account ledgers. Field served as treasurer for many Durham organizations. Personal tax and investment information has been removed when identified.

The Name and Correspondence Files document Field's personal relationships and his communications as an author and community activist. Files are not strictly correspondence; some include artwork, writings, and publications, including zines and newsletters. Materials are filed by author/creator.

Finally, Field's personal materials include childhood and adolescent scrapbooks and yearbooks; photographs and snapshots with friends and family; headshots and portraits of Field; and personal accounting and financial ledgers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains board minutes, correspondence, financial accounts, grant application materials, photographs, and other materials from the administration, group meetings, and retreats led or sponsored by Collaborations.

did.unittitle: The Regulator bookshop administrative and legal materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Board minutes, notes, and legal documents about the founding and expansion of Durham's Regulator bookshop.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Field's ledgers and notes from The Regulator bookshop and its parent company, Top of the Ninth, including income and expense reports and other financial tracking materials, largely dating from the 1980s and early 1990s.

did.unittitle: The Regulator Community Fund/Helen Whiting Scholarship Fund

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials documenting The Regulator's fundraising and sponsorship of scholarships and local Durham community organizations, through the Community Fund and the Helen Whiting memorial Scholarship Fund.

did.unittitle: "Tao: A New Way of Thinking" text
Town of Cary: Page-Walker Center workshops

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, financial materials, and production notes from Field's role in the founding and publication of Urban Hiker magazine. Also contains complete issues of Urban Hiker from July 2003-December 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscripts, research, drafts, and final versions of Field's poems, plays, and prose. Titles include: Ajose; The Bathtub Caper; The Bobber-Cat (zine); The Caldron of Story; Coffee, Beer, Never Fear; the Duke University Yearbook (Vol. 63, 1975); The End of the World Brain; Germination; Eros, or Myself; The Mercy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscripts, drafts, research, and final versions of Field's poems, plays, and prose. Titles included in this box: A Morris Dance; Obvious Knowledge; The Plenum; Savannah: The Pool of Reflection; The Secret Name; Soft Changes; Something's Up/The Princess and the Nemo; A Southern Friendship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Works-in-Progress binder with drafts and outlines

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, artwork, and writings by Field's friends, lovers, and relatives. Notable files include the Broughton family, Lawrence Bullock, Mark Cunningham (including several files of original artwork), Guy Davenport, Andre Fernandes, and Aden's parents, the Fields.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publication: Stories of Home and the Mobile Gallery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, writings, artwork, and publications from Field's friends, lovers, and family. Notable names in this box include Field's parents, Maggie Henniss, Scott and Justine Jackson-Ricketts, and Gioia and Everett Palmieri. Also includes zine titles Mineshaft (filed under Palmieri, the authors) and Free Fan Zines, and drafts of Royal Sorceress (by Justine Jackson-Ricketts) and The Dog Man (by Barry Jacobs).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, writings, and artwork from Field's family, friends, and lovers. Notable names in this box include Rich Robeson, Rebecca Ranson, V.C. Rogers (including a copy of Peripheral Visions, his cartoons), and Worth (Buzz) and Susan Weller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Canvas boards painted by Philip (last name uncertain) between 1975 and 1976.
